data.title: Allow YAML for all configuration files
data.body:
JSON has a couple of issues:
- Many things need to be escaped
- Not human-readable very well
- No line breaks in strings
- No advanced features like repeating/references
- comments are not officially supported

I propose that VS Code supports YAML aswell as JSON for all config files (settings.json, launch.json, tasks.json, snippets.json). Especially for Snippets it would be much better experience, but also for tasks etc. As YAML is a superset of JSON the current JSON schema can be mapped 1:1 to YAML.

For example, VS Code should look for a launch.json file, and if it doesn't find one, look for a setting.yaml file.

This would of course depend on IntelliSense support for YAML with JSON schemas (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1176)

data.title: "Install shell command `code` doesn't do anything"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.13 Insiders
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the insiders 0.10.13 Insiders build
2. Open VS Code and run the "Install `code` command in PATH" utility from the command palette.
3. restart terminal
4. try to run `code`
5. nothing happens

Checked `.bashrc`, `.bash_profile`, and `.zshrc` (`zsh` is actually my shell, but I checked the `bash` ones just to be safe) and saw no evidence that VS Code had tried to write anything.

data.title: Customizable 'Open in Command Prompt' console
data.body: _Open in Command Prompt_ currently opens `cmd.exe`, it would be nice to customize it to run e.g. Cmder or ConEmu which are much better alternatives.

data.title: closeAllFiles does not close Default Settings and Default Keyboard Shortcuts
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Bind a keyboard shortcut to `workbench.files.action.closeAllFiles`
2. Open either `File -> Preferences -> User Settings` or `File -> Preferences -> Keyboard Shortcuts`
3. Observe that the right-hand pane shows your editable settings file and either `Default Settings` or `Default Keyboard Shortcuts`, respectively.
4. Press your keyboard shortcut for `workbench.files.action.closeAllFiles`
5. Observe that the right-hand pane closes but the left-hand pane (`Default Settings` or `Default Keyboard Shortcuts`) remains open.

Intriguingly, if you open multiple files in multiple panes, `workbench.files.action.closeAllFiles` behaves exactly as one would expect and closes all of them, returning you to an empty workspace.

data.title: Icons in Windows Explorer are overrided
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Feb. stable build (0.10.11)
- OS Version: Win 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Install VSCode.
2.  See any code file in Explorer, icons are changed to vscode style, and cannot tell out C#/C++/H/etc...

Please add an option to choose whether to use VSCode file icon or not.

PS: This problem doesn't appears in insider build 0.10.13.

data.title: Getting multiple info pop-ups after installing Cordova extension and they are contradictory.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version:Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create Cordova project structure using Yeoman (Proj type WIndows8 Mobile app).
2. Launch VS code and open proj root folder.
3. Click on extensions Icon from the status bar and select option for install extension.
4. Select Cordova extension and install it.
5. Verify extension should be installed successfully and user should get info pop-up to restart the window.

Actual: Getting two info pop-up as below and those are contradictory.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14194766/c3f69bbe-f766-11e5-8de0-4dfe5a887446.png)

Expected: Only one pop-up as below:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14194774/dabdc58e-f766-11e5-8bb1-96ec3a8239dc.png)

data.title: Extensions recommendations list is not displaying Cordova extension when opening Cordova project.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create Cordova project structure using Yeoman. (Project Type Windows 8 mobile app)
2. Launch VS code and open root directory of Cordova project.
3. Click on extension info icon from the status bar.
4. Select options for Extension recommendations and verify list.

Actual: Not getting option for Cordova extension.
Expected: It should identify project type and display recommendations list accordingly.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14194631/653b70aa-f765-11e5-8503-30256adddd17.png)

data.title: Allow to disable drag and drop in the files explorer
data.body:
It would be interesting to be able to disable the _drag and drop_ operations in the TreeView, mostly to avoid _mistakes_ :disappointed: 

Another option it would be to make the _Undo/Redo_ operations to work for the TreeView operations.

Thanks in advance

data.title: No hover values for long watch variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start debugging
2. Find a heavily nested variable to add to watch and/or slide the debug bar to the left so it is very thin.

Actual:
Hovering over watched variables does not display their value. If there is a heavily nested variable, even expanding the debug section to the right as far as it goes still displays ... and there is no way to see the value.

data.title: Debugging express prototype/constructor variables infinitely nested
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a Node.js Express application (I'm using https://github.com/heroku/node-js-sample)
2. Set a breakpoint inside index.js at line 4 (app.set('port', ...)
3. Start debugging 
4. Expand express: function createApplication() {...}
5. Expand Application: Object
6. Expand checkout: function (path){...}
7. Expand prototype: Object
8. Repeat steps 6 and 7

Actual:
Can expand these 2 indefinitely

data.title: Git output shows --allow-empty-message command after commit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha (latest)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Modify a file 
2. Stage changes and add a commit message.
3. Show Git output

Actual:
Git output shows the --allow-empty-message command during the commit, but a message is required when using commit in VS Code

Is this by design? I notice it does show the commit message after pushing to GitHub.

data.title: Color file types in Explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce: Explorer bar

When finding files in the Explorer, my eyes have trouble focusing. File types like .js, .html, and .css could be colored to easier distinguish them from one another.

data.title: Regular expression ".*" does not match anything
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 0.10.11
  Commit f291f4ad600767626b24a4b15816b04bee9a3049
  Date 2016-03-11T17:10:35.304Z
  Shell 0.35.6
  Renderer 45.0.2454.85
  Node 4.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise SP1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Ctrl+F, then turn on Regex (Alt+R)
2. Find `^.*$`
   ==> Bug. Does not match any lines

Note that `.*` doesn't match anything either. 
Also note that `..*` (or for a full line `^..*$`) matches, but only lines with at least one character
Also note that `^.?.*$` does not match anything either. --> Bug

data.title: Minor tool-tip correction
data.body:
Makes tool-tip consistent with class description, and consistent with "Working Files" tool-tips.

Helps avoid new-user confusion (a new user might think "Collapse" collapses the work-space rather than all the contained folders in the work-space).

data.title: CPP `dotnet restore --configfile NuGet.Config` fails
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11 (February 2016)
- OS Version: 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install VSCode
2. install ext install cpptools according https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.cpptools

The at step  4: dotnet restore --configfile NuGet.Config.

I get the following error:
dotnet restore --configfile NuGet.Config
log  : Restoring packages for /Users/pmueller/.vscode/extensions/ms-vscode.cpptools-0.4.1/project.json...
error: Failed to retrieve information from remote source '/Users/pmueller/.nuget/packages/'.

...

error: Unable to load the service index for source https://www.myget.org/F/dotnet-core/api/v3/index.json.
error:   The type initializer for 'Crypto' threw an exception.
error:   Unable to load DLL 'System.Security.Cryptography.Native': The specified module could not be found.
error:    (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)

How can I fix this?
Thanks,
Peter

data.title: Add CJK-aware line wrapping, and basic Kinsoku Shori () to Visual Studio Code
data.body: The main idea is adding a forth character class, `BREAK_IDEOGRAPHIC`, which behaves normally like both `BREAK_BEFORE_CLASS` and `BREAK_AFTER_CLASS`, unless it is before a `BREAK_AFTER_CLASS` character, or after a `BREAK_BEFORE_CLASS` character.

data.title: Code coloring incorrect for 'implements' when 'extends' is also used
data.body:
- VSCode Version:0.10.11
- OS Version:Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add class with signature like:
   `export class MyClass extends MyBaseClass implements MyInterface`
2. See that `implements` is incorrectly colored green instead of blue (at least in the default color scheme).  If you remove `extends MyBaseClass`, then `implements` is properly colored blue.

data.title: Show hover on launch config gear
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

I had a syntactically broken launch.json without being aware of it. It showed up in VS Code like this:

![2016-03-31 11-46-28](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14172008/4bfa27aa-f736-11e5-96c9-9bd2ae227e70.png)

The gear icon showed a red dot which I hadn't seen before and I didn't know what it means.
Hovering over it did not show anything.
I did not spot the tiny squiggly on the opening brace '{'.
I was stuck!

At least we should show a hover on the gear that clearly states that the launch.json is fundamentally broken.

And showing errors more prominently in the json would help too... Why is the squiggly green and not red? It has a fatal error that cannot be ignored.

data.title: Renaming file marks for git delete but not git add
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.13-insider
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.10586]

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder of a project using git version control
2. In VCS 'Explorer', right-click file in the folder view (under Working Files) and rename it
3. Switch to Git view.
4. Notice that old name of the file is marked D for delete, and the new name is U for untracked.
5. Outside of VCS, use `git mv` to rename a file, and see VCS correctly picks up the change as 'R' (presumably for 'renamed').
